I love the two programmable buttons on the back. I play Rocket League occasionally and got fully adjusted to triggers on the back of the controller to maneuver my car and without them I lose a lot of skill. These triggers, while not as nice as the Elite triggers, are simply and fully functional and are positioned properly so your fingers naturally reach them when needed. Overall a very good controller and under $60 so it's a nice value for what seems like a quality product.

CommentsTitle: Honestly a pretty great budget option
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 9, 2020
CommentsContent: I just recently started streaming on Twitch and have never owned a controller for playing specifically PC games before. I was playing The Witcher 3 and Remnant From the Ashes with my Switch Pro controller with some success, but transitioning from PC to Switch was becoming a pain, so I bought this controller just to play PC games.I had reservations buying a third-party controller, but this one is right on the money. It's plug and play simplicity. No messing around with Bluetooth settings or drivers. Plug it into a USB and you're off to the races.Pros:The outer shell material of the controller feels similar to a matt finish and feels great in my hands while playing for hours on end. I live in a hot climate so sweat sometimes becomes an issue when playing games with slick features, but this controller has no issues with that.The button on the back to switch between the various colors is neatly tucked away behind the back on the controller, and it's never an issue while playing games that require quick reaction times. Having the option to change colors is nice, but is purely a cosmetic feature.Cons:Despite feeling great in my hands, the controller can sometimes feel a bit light and frankly a little cheap in some areas. The buttons and triggers are responsive, but I feel like I have to baby them if I want them to last. (I'm protective of my gear anyway, but it's still worth considering if your the type of player who throws controllers). Some of the buttons on the back feel unneeded. I have no idea what the purpose of the T1, T2, and T3 levers on the back of the controller are used for, and the programable buttons, while an interesting idea, don't serve much of a purpose in my honest opinion.Conclusion:Finding first-party controllers during the era of COVID can be an absolute nightmare due to price gouging and supply scarcity, so if you want to buy a slightly less expensive alternative that simply "works" then this is the controller for you. This is plug and play simplicity at it's finest. If that's what you want along with some minor cosmetic flair, then I'd recommend picking up one of these puppies. If you want something with weighted buttons and more substantial-quality, then you may want to look eslewhere.

CommentsTitle: Works pretty well. RGB a gimmick. Worth the price
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 22, 2020
CommentsContent: The construction is quite good.  It feels solid in your hand.  It's not feather light like the really cheap controllers.  The buttons are responsive, the thumb sticks are precise and smooth.  The D-pad works well and the vibration is strong and well defined.  The cable is MicroUSB and while it can be replaced with most standard cables, the cable it comes with is customized to snap in place and stay there firmly.  It is also plenty long, of good quality, and sleeved.  The mfg does have a support site where you can download updated firmware.  And there was a firmware update which I installed.  It also has a "Calibration" mode.  So, if it were not working properly you could re-calibrate and it might help.Here's the NOT SO GOOD:  The RGB is essentially pointless but if you're into that kind of thing so be it.  The button mapping onto the "paddle" buttons works the same as other controllers but I wish they had added the ability to map select and start as well. It would have been nice if they'd added a turbo or macro function which would have made it a lot more useful (they did not).  Also, they are a little bit awkward to press sometimes, but maybe that's just me.Compared to Microsoft XBOX ONE Bluetooth controller (Model 1708).  The 1708 controller is basic, it is lacking the paddle buttons and any kind of trigger locks.  The Analog sticks feel identical.  I can't tell a difference except that the Microsoft controller thumbstick caps are rubber and they are hard plastic on this one.  That's always the first thing that wears out on Microsoft controllers (in my experience) so that may be a good thing.  I never felt these were uncomfortable to use or anything.  The Trigger buttons on the 1708 feel better than these.  These aren't bad, just not quite as "premium" feeling.  However, the ABXY buttons on this controller are better.  After using this one for a week the ones on the 1708 feel cheap by comparison.  This controller is covered with a rubberized texture which feels much nicer than the hard plastic on the 1708.  However, it also shows the oils from your fingers quite well (mostly on the select and start buttons because they are smaller) and I find myself cleaning it often.  Also, these kinds of rubberized coatings usually degrade over time into a sticky mess but to be fair I don't know if that's going to happen here.  Finally the vibration on this controller is noticeably stronger than the 1708, probably because it's a wired controller.Overall, it's a good, solid controller with a couple extra features you may or may not care about.  For the money it's VERY worth it and you could do much much worse.  I would buy it again.

Ever got something you wanted for Christmas, but it ended up being an inferior version of what you actually wanted, and you hated it but couldn't say anything without being rude? This is how your son will feel if you buy any other third party controller available nowadays. If you want to ensure nobody is suffering in silence, buy this. Besides, those lights are really cool.*For the Gamers:Alright, lets get down to business.Build Quality:XYAB feels the same as XBOX. LB RB and D-Pad has the same tactile feel as an Apple TV remote or any similar thin clicky remotes. USB cord and connection is solid. Once you plug it in, that sucker is NOT coming out. Holding firmly with both hands and twisting like trying to wring out a towel results in zero squeaking. I'm really trying to break this thing. It's not making any noise. LT and RT have a good resistance, not too little not too much.Lights:Very strong but diffused so it's easy on the eyes and doesn't have any "strong" spots. Swiveling the analog sticks around will reveal dim spots, but just barely.Rumble:Not much to say here. Similar to XBOX. A little less refined maybe, but that's a good thing because it makes it feel a bit more intense.Sensitivity and Deadzones, the Most Important Thing That Nobody Talks About:Let's face it, you buy controllers nowadays for games that require fine control. The ranges of motion on LT, RT, and the analog sticks are extremely important. I can't for the life of me find the proper term for what I'm about to describe, so I'll just be referring to them as "Physical Range", and "Virtual Range".Physical Range is the literal range of motion available to you on the input. On RT, unpressed is 0% and pressed all the way down is 100%. Virtual Range is what the software reads. The key to good controllers and the thing that plagues bad controllers is the relationship between the Virtual Ranges and the Physical Ranges on your inputs (more specifically, where the virtual range lies on the physical). On an XBOX controller, pushing the physical down to 5% will do nothing, the software still thinks you're at 0%. It is only when you get to around 6% physical input that the software will register 1% input. This is the "dead-zone". Also for XBOX, reaching about 95% physical input will result in 100% virtual input on the software, and pushing it any further will make no difference. This is the "bottom-out". What this means is from 0-5% and 95-100%, nothing is happening. It is only at 5-95% that you have any real influence on the inputs. XBOX is good, but 10% of the motion you paid 60 bucks for is not available to you, and that sucks.Herein lies the problem with third party controllers. Other than a really good controller I had 10 years ago (also by PowerA but now discontinued), all the physical vs. virtual ranges have been absolutely atrocious. Most controllers have ranges on 30-100% (huge dead-zone), or ranges on 0-70% (huge bottom-out). My latest purchase from RegeModual had its range on 0-40%. I couldn't believe it. I returned it and got this controller instead. Boy, was I surprised. The ranges are 0-100%, a perfect 1-to-1 ratio. Yeah, that's right, its better than XBOX. To my knowledge, NO other controllers are this good. Not even PowerA's 20 dollar controller on amazon (sorry PowerA). Everything else sucks. XBOX controllers suck. This is how it should be.If you care at all about really having a good controller, this is all that matters. Aiming properly in FPS, feathering your throttle in racing sims, edge-lord slow-walking in Dark Souls, all of this can only be done with good input ranges, and this is the gold standard. Forget the flashy lights, the build quality, the price, the ease-of-use, etc. The biggest indicator of quality is this, and for some reason, nobody talks about it. If you don't believe me, buy this and you'll realize how much better gaming feels.I've included a video of this. As you can see, the input ranges are matched up perfectly.Longevity:Just bought this and I've only logged a few hours on it. Right out of the box, it feels incredible. I would have easily paid double the price of an XBOX controller. However, only time will tell if this controller holds up. So far, I expect this controller to last at least 1000 hours of use before any significant signs of wear. It'll probably last much longer. Obviously, your mileage may vary, but as long as you don't throw this thing across the room every time you get headshotted, I fully expect this to stand the test of time.Take a look at how old my review is. If anything breaks or any inputs get wonky, I'll be adding an edit to my review to let you guys know. If there are no edits down below, it means it's still going strong.Seriously, just get this controller. I'm not receiving anything from the company or amazon to give it a favorable review, it's just that good. I'm doing this because I know the pain of dealing with crappy controllers, and I want to help people out. I hope this has been helpful. Have an awesome day. :)

CommentsContent: If you're like me then you've always been hesitant to give third party controllers a fair shake. Companies like Mad Catz kind of gave third party controllers a bad wrap but this controller is an excellent substitute for a first party one.Pros:- Analog sticks. For me, this is the biggest reason I usually avoid third party controllers. They've typically been terrible feeling and unresponsive, not this controller though. The analog sticks feel great and are extremely responsive, I have no issues in first person shooters. In terms of feel, I'd say they're pretty akin to the 1st party Xbone controller. Looser than say, a Dualshock 4 and a 360 controller, but not too loose where it feels. Absolutely excellent job on the sticks.- Trigger stops. I've never had a controller with trigger stops before so this was a unique experience for me. I've grown to like this for certain games like shooters, but I typically keep them off.- 2 programmable buttons. I have to admit, I don't use these things much. I've only used them in FPS games where its awkward to jump and still aim. They do the job well and its a cool feature.- Buttons are all responsive and feel nice. The d-pad is a step above what you'd usually expect on an Xbox controller but its nothing to right home about, it feels responsive and does the job.- The controller looks and feels cool. I think the appearance of the controller is what draws a lot of people in and it definitely lives up to it in person. It looks absolutely amazing with the RGB lights on and the overall finish on the controller just looks clean and great.- It's wired. Some people may see this as a con, but for me its a pro. I mainly use my controller for PC gaming and so wireless doesn't really interest me. I don't want to deal with charging my battery or possible input lag, I just want a controller I can plug in and work. The cable itself is braided and high quality, and it comes with a Velcro strap for easy cable management.Neutral:- The connector is Micro USB. Normally this would be a huge con, heck a deal breaker for me. Micro USB is possibly the worst connector ever made, it wears out easily over time and becomes loose and disconnects often after awhile. People who have owned a Dualshock 4 or any device with it probably have experienced this. To have it on a purely wired controller, that does not work without the wire I might add, seemed like a huge misstep to me. However, PowerA in their infinite wisdom seem to have thought this through. The USB connector is snugly recessed into the controller and the cable itself has hooks on the side which keep the connector firmly in place. That means even if the physically connection does wear out through unplugging the controller, its not likely to affect much.This is all fine and dandy, and I'm glad they realized the connector was bad, but this brings about its own issues. The USB cable that came with the controller is not easily replaceable since it relies on the hooks on the connector to keep it in place. Two, since the USB connection on the controller is recessed in a small hole on the controller, you have to be really careful about which cable you buy for it. Basically, finding a replacement USB cable for this thing is going to be a nightmare. Their solution seems completely unnecessary when they could have just put a better connector instead of Micro USB to begin with.If you're buying this controller, I HIGHLY recommend never removing the USB cable from the controller once its in.Cons:- I praised the trigger stops earlier but they're not perfect. There are 3 settings, normal which is no stops, medium, and full stops. I don't know what the cause is, but the trigger stops on the highest setting just outright don't work for some games. Most games I've tried do work though, so this is kind of a baffling issue. I suspect it has to do with sensitivity and how much the trigger stop pushes physically on the button. However, this issue only exists on the highest setting of the trigger stops. The medium setting and normal setting don't have this issue.- The finish. The controller looks damn cool and the finish looks really nice, but you sacrifice a bit for those looks. The controller has a rubberized kind of texture on the face, and there's no getting around it, this finish is absolutely terrible for a controller. It's a fingerprint magnet of the highest degree and if your hands are even remotely sweaty, this controller won't be doing you any favors. On the bright side, the finish is easy to clean with a damp paper towel and a microfiber cloth. I've been able to get it back to good as new fairly easily, but boy, this thing looks ugly even after one gaming session.Overall, I gave this a 4/5. I would like to see a revision of this controller with a more robust connector and a different finish on it, but even so I've had a great experience with this thing. Would recommend.

They used a clamping design that prevents accidental disconnections and its incredibly rugged. Gives off the impression that it will have no issues surviving a knock to the ground.  I haven't tried that but it's good to know that there is a better chance of it surviving a fall then a normal micro usb connected one.The RGB lighting is self contained and can be very easily adjusted on the fly by pressing the button on the back of the controller. Speaking of the back of the controller, it has trigger stays that can be adjusted with a switch making it again very easy for on the fly changes.  There are also 2 programmable buttons that are very comfortable to use. They are assigned by pressing and holding down the button above the RGB one until the power led light on the front starts to flash. Then all you need to do is push whatever you want to assign to it and your done. Again all adjustment are so simple that it can be changed in a matter of seconds during a session and you don't need any software to get it done.I have over 50 hours with it and have expedience no performance issues at all. This is a very solid build device.Now for why its 4 stars.That beautiful mat black finish. Well you really need to take a few selfies with it. Maybe introduce it to your parents and possibly a nice dinner. Because after about your 10th hour in it's going to turn into a pumpkin.  There will be wear marks all over the place. To the point that it's rather ugly and very old looking.  Seriously I don't know what they were thinking. My friends were over the day I took it out of the box. They were interested in it until they watched it go from a shelve queen to a dumpster fire almost over night. This is completely avoidable and I'm rather confused as to why it was green lit.The only other complaint I have with it is with the trigger stays. They can be so easily adjusted on the fly that accidental movement is a thing and if your not aware confusion will be a foot. I have lost races and a few gun battles because of this. It's not a deal breaker now, whenever it happens I just flick it back into position.  But the first couple of times it's going to frustrate you.Over all if your looking for a wired controller and don't mind the wear issues with the finish. You really can't go wrong with it. This is by far the best controller I have played within this price point.
